35.88.text:
This is going to be an unusual episode of
Holy Hallucinations, so before I begin I’m

40.05.text:
going to take a few moments to explain how
it came about. I was recently contacted by

45.11.text:
the user TheSouleater37, who’s writing a
book on religion and atheism that’ll include

49.86.text:
contributions from such great Youtubers as
DPRJones, ProportionalResponse, Brettppalmer,

55.48.text:
and GreatBigBore.
Souleater not only asked for permission to

59.25.text:
quote me, but also whether I’d mind answering,
in my own YouTube style, some allegedly unanswerable

64.39.text:
questions posed by a theist. Since I normally
prefer to just stick to defending science

69.79.text:
I wasn’t entirely sure whether to accept
such an open invitation, but in the end I

74.23.text:
agreed and soon afterward was furnished with
a list of banalities from none other than

78.42.text:
that greasy little car-salesman of an apologist,
Casey Luskin of the Discovery Institute of

84.31.text:
Misinformation and Downright Dishonesty.
Now some of these are questions that I’d

89.58.text:
not normally address because they’re either
outside my area of expertise; or not designed

94.22.text:
to discredit science; or are to do with the
existence of God, who I’m not primarily

98.53.text:
here to try to disprove. However, because
I didn’t want to be accused of evasiveness,

102.86.text:
I decided to answer them all to the best of
my ability.

106.08.text:
And since I’d taken the time to do that,
I thought it would be silly not to kill two

109.83.text:
birds with one stone and use my answers as
the basis for a Holy Hallucinations episode.

114.41.text:
So with all that said, let’s cut to the
chase and take a look the pungent and crusty

120.00.text:
cerebral stools that our friend Casey thought
would be so perplexing.

126.27.text:
“What is the origin of matter?”
The currently accepted best explanation of

131.53.text:
the observable evidence (such as universal
expansion, the relative abundance of hydrogen

135.69.text:
and helium and the cosmic microwave background),
is that our universe, and not only all the

140.27.text:
matter and energy in it but also space and
time, arose from the expansion of a singularity

144.47.text:
approximately 13.8 billion years ago.
As to what happened before that? Well, while

150.29.text:
I’m not a physicist it’s my understanding
that this is an area of active research and

154.06.text:
that numerous speculative hypotheses have
been proposed. At the moment however, the

158.43.text:
only honest answer is; “I don’t know.”
And anyone who says that they do know, particularly

165.37.text:
if they’re claiming knowledge that posits
that some kind of supernatural but suspiciously

169.45.text:
ephemeral entity is responsible, is nothing
more than either a self-deluded or lying bag

174.87.text:
of stale piss. Because in reality, just like
the rest of us, they don’t know. They’re

180.90.text:
just asserting they know or thinking wishfully
because their childish, feeble minds aren’t

185.08.text:
able to grow up and accept the reality that
in the big scary world not everything’s

189.36.text:
certain and that there may not be someone
out there to hold your hand when you need

193.51.text:
to go poopy.
The inability of science to currently explain

197.65.text:
any given phenomenon in no way lends credence
to the existence of any god either past, present

202.79.text:
or as yet to be conjured up by the minds of
men. If you want to make the claim that your

207.57.text:
God is responsible, then kindly provide both
empirical and verifiable evidence of his existence

212.73.text:
and the mechanisms He employed in creating
matter, or admit that you have no rational

217.56.text:
grounds for this claim and are just chalking
it up to magic because it’s easier than

221.02.text:
thinking about it. If you won’t do either
then kindly just shut up and piss off.

228.66.text:
“What is the origin of information in DNA?”
Science of course, has developed a number

236.40.text:
of hypotheses with regard to the origin of
the first self-replicating polymers and produced

240.64.text:
evidence to support many aspects of these
ideas. So while no definitive answer’s been

245.62.text:
arrived at in this nascent but rapidly growing
field of study, it is disingenuous of you

250.68.text:
in the extreme to act as if this is a completely
undressed and seemingly intractable problem

255.51.text:
in modern biology.
If you had paid attention in college and spent

259.37.text:
less time learning to chase ambulances for
a living, you might have realized this and

263.78.text:
not been doomed to making yourself look like
an ignorant boob in public by asking stupid

269.28.text:
questions.
Of course the other possibility is that you’re

272.00.text:
well aware of concepts such as the RNA World
hypothesis, ribozymes and hypercycles, but

276.81.text:
are deliberately ignoring them because you’re
a despicably dishonest fraud who doesn’t

281.62.text:
care how big or how repugnant the lies he
tells to push his agenda are, or about the

286.68.text:
consequences of pushing them. Making specific
criticisms of scientific ideas and generating

292.25.text:
evidence to discredit them is one thing, but
ignoring their existence entirely is evidence

297.46.text:
of only your abhorrent dishonesty
DNA doesn’t contain any information in the

302.85.text:
sense that you and you fellow creationists
like to refer to. It is a complex polymer

307.53.text:
built from four basic monomeric units that
can be arranged in specific sequences to form

311.99.text:
unique structures. It is these structures
that drive cellular chemical reactions in

316.73.text:
specific directions to produce other specific
polymers with their own specific structures

321.12.text:
and specific functions.
You’re bastardizing the word “information”

325.87.text:
from the fact that these structures can and
have been described by humans in a convenient

329.78.text:
four-letter shorthand. It is only once these
sequences have been written down by humans

334.35.text:
and stored in computers that they become what
you refer to as information, but, they remain

339.19.text:
what they always were - nothing more than
complex chemicals with equally complex chemical

343.90.text:
properties with the context of a cell.
In hindsight, it’s unfortunate that scientists

348.99.text:
adopted the code analogy in the development
of the fields of molecular biology and genetics,

353.49.text:
using words such as “information”, “codon”,
“transcript”, and “message”. Though

357.53.text:
to be fair to them, how were they to know
that this technical jargon was destined to

361.07.text:
be hijacked by a disingenuous cadre of filthy
shysters who would later use it to imply that

366.55.text:
such “information” could only be produced
by an intelligent mind? And not just any mind

371.86.text:
either, but the one described in particular
primitive and childishly simplistic fables

376.20.text:
written long, long ago by a collection of
ignorant goat molesters.

381.10.text:
So now that I’ve explained why you’re
yet again being dishonest with your language,

384.82.text:
and why you’re ignoring large swathes of
work that provide glimpses of the answers

388.43.text:
to this question, answers rooted in observable
and quantifiable phenomena, perhaps you could

393.82.text:
do us the honor of providing your alternative,
Casey?

397.71.text:
And remember if what you come up with, once
you’ve stripped away the fancy and illusory

401.51.text:
words you use to tart it up like a cheap harlot
on a street corner, in the end only amounts

406.30.text:
to “God did it”, then that’s fine. Just
be prepared to accept that your alternative

411.16.text:
is rooted in primitive superstition and not
modern rationality.

415.27.text:
But if you can’t bring yourself to do that
because you don’t want to look like and

418.22.text:
ignorant ass-hat who prefers to place his
stock in fables and not facts, then please

423.22.text:
instead provide alternatives that are both
credible and testable and also some empirical

427.62.text:
evidence to support them. If you can’t or
won’t, then I’d prefer it if you would

432.28.text:
just shut up and piss off.
“How does consciousness work?”

441.43.text:
I’m starting to discern a pattern in these
questions, so before I go on to give my answer

445.96.text:
I want to build on something I said earlier.
You, see, all you seem to be doing so far

450.59.text:
is picking on a random physical phenomenon
for which science has as yet not found a fully

454.61.text:
comprehensive explanation, and using it to
imply that the only possible cause for the

459.38.text:
said phenomenon is your ephemeral, all-powerful,
and yet curiously anthropic pal.

465.10.text:
So if the purpose of your questions is to
convince people that He actually exists and

469.06.text:
is merely suffering from a terminal case of
shyness, then might I suggest that you’d

473.44.text:
be much better served by doing something to
demonstrate that He has an actual basis in

477.60.text:
reality and isn’t just the product of the
collective hallucinations of primitive barbarians.

483.12.text:
Of course I realize that it’s a lot easier
to sit back on your arse and pick holes in

487.14.text:
a work in progress rather than doing some
actual fucking work yourself, or for that

491.42.text:
matter anything that might even remotely be
interpreted as being intellectually honest,

496.87.text:
particularly since your fellow believers have
been vainly trying to produce such evidence

500.42.text:
for two millennia. Instead they’ve presented
us with nothing but a string of wishful philosophical

505.40.text:
musings that have to struggle to convince
anyone with even a vaguely open mind to keep

509.72.text:
their faith, let alone convince a freethinker
to adopt it.

513.96.text:
While this laziness on your part somewhat
pisses me off, it doesn’t do so half as

518.32.text:
much as your refusal to own up to the consequence
of your inability to explain exactly how your

523.65.text:
god produced these phenomena. Because, at
the end of the day, the answer’s “magic”,

528.36.text:
isn’t it Casey? I strongly suspect that
you and your fellow tribesmen know exactly

533.53.text:
how stupid it would look for adults to actually
come out and admit that, so that’s why you

538.70.text:
avoid the word like the plague. Instead you
rubbish the work of some of the greatest minds

544.15.text:
in history to propagate your spurious claims,
without having the balls to come out and show

548.46.text:
the world how ludicrously childish your alternative
actually is.

553.38.text:
So with that said, let’s get back to the
matter in hand. While I know virtually nothing

557.56.text:
about the field of cognitive neuroscience,
it appears that my knowledge in this area

561.41.text:
is still infinitely greater than yours, Casey
- that is to say that I at least know a little

566.29.text:
more than fuck-all about it.
That’s because I’ve read at least enough

570.21.text:
to know that while a comprehensive and detailed
explanation of consciousness is not yet within

574.42.text:
our grasp, the phenomenon is no longer the
complete mystery that you seem to be implying

578.94.text:
it is. In fact it seems fairly clear that
consciousness is an emergent property of a

583.55.text:
highly complex arrangement of an unimaginably
vast array of interacting neurons.

589.16.text:
We know that because we can consistently image
the same areas of the brain humming with activity

593.98.text:
following administration of the appropriate
physical or psychological stimuli; we observe

599.01.text:
that damage to specific brain areas reproducibly
results in the same cognitive dysfunctions;

604.64.text:
we are able to reliably reproduce specific
emotions and behaviors upon physical stimulation

609.55.text:
of specific areas of the brain; and we know
of countless chemical compounds that affect

614.27.text:
a stunning myriad of emotional and neuromotor
functions and understand the molecular basis

619.24.text:
for their physical modes of action.
Furthermore, it’s been demonstrated that

623.21.text:
consciousness itself may not at all be what
our subjective experiences think it is. It’s

628.21.text:
been demonstrated conclusively that the subconscious
brain can make decisions up to a full ten

633.00.text:
seconds before the mind fools itself into
thinking that it was responsible. This not

638.03.text:
only suggests that our inner workings are
a lot more mechanical than we give them credit

642.31.text:
for, but also casts a serious shadow over
the concept of free-will, that old favorite

647.10.text:
that your kind use to rationalize why your
God is justified in acting like a complete

652.60.text:
dip-shit.
Now I realize that ‘tards like you look

656.46.text:
upon the honest admission that there is still
more to learn about anything as profoundly

660.43.text:
unsatisfying and feel that your explanation
(which in reality explains nothing) is somehow

666.40.text:
superior, especially if you assert it as fact
with enough conviction.

670.58.text:
In this particular case, I assume that your
explanation for the phenomenon of consciousness,

675.37.text:
at least in part, involves that, yet again,
invisible and undetectable entity known as

680.01.text:
a soul. With that in mind, rather than just
rubbishing the explanation that actually has

684.90.text:
some evidence to support it, why don’t you
stop asking stupid and disingenuous questions

690.28.text:
and instead take a stab at expounding on what
the soul is, what it’s made of, where we

695.53.text:
can find it and exactly how it influences
and interacts with the material world. Otherwise,

701.01.text:
then please, just shut up and piss off.
“Why is there a universal morality?”

711.31.text:
This one’s easy, because there isn’t one,
and the only people I have ever heard claiming

715.35.text:
that a universal objective morality exists
are those with a religious agenda. This seems

720.42.text:
to be done while simultaneously ignoring mountains
of evidently observable and historically documented

725.87.text:
evidence that morality is a fluid and continually
evolving social construct created by people.

731.80.text:
What is considered moral in one culture can
be regarded as downright abhorrent in another.

736.81.text:
For example, I’d warrant, Casey, that you’d
consider that cutting someone’s hand off

740.62.text:
for stealing is an immoral act, but there
are many on this planet with convictions as

744.85.text:
strong as yours who might disagree. I personally
think that what a man does with his own John

750.39.text:
Thomas, and who he does it with, is something
best left to him and the four walls, whereas

755.27.text:
many who share your beliefs would judge him
a monster should he choose to use it to play

759.19.text:
hide the sausage with Pillsbury Doughboy.
And even within your own cult, Casey, you

764.51.text:
have fine Christians who think it’s perfectly
acceptable to murder abortion providers while

768.53.text:
the majority of your fellow believers would
condemn such action as morally reprehensible.

773.28.text:
Historically, the Romans thought nothing of
watching men slaughter each other, or of feeding

777.73.text:
people to wild animals for entertainment.
Nor was the rape of women by soldiers always

782.58.text:
considered off-limits, as depicted by your
very own bible and also in countless historical

787.33.text:
works of non-fiction. Even the mutilation
and torture of people who had the gall to

792.04.text:
not share the beliefs of your fellow Christians
was at one point not even considered to be

796.32.text:
a social faux-pas, and to be honest I suspect
there might still be a few hidden amongst

801.01.text:
your ilk who secretly yearn for the return
of those good old days.

805.22.text:
Of course, I suspect that you’ll dismiss
all these examples by claiming they just reflect

808.98.text:
the actions of imperfect men and not the will
of your perfectly camouflaged moral law-giver.

814.17.text:
I say this because I’ve lost count of the
times I’ve heard the same old philosophical

817.89.text:
arguments for absolute morality from dishonest
old fuckers who seem to spend all their time

822.41.text:
peddling them as hard as they can, instead
of actually trying to produce some evidence

826.58.text:
to support them.
So rather than asserting that such transcendental

830.34.text:
morals do exist based on nothing but sophistic
word games and wishful thinking, why don’t

835.55.text:
you grow a pair of balls and support your
claim by providing us with some credible and

839.51.text:
independently verifiable evidence for the
existence your law giver? Or just shut up

844.98.text:
and piss off.
“If Darwinian evolution simply requires

852.51.text:
survival and reproduction, why do humans compose
symphonies, write poetry, worship God, discover

858.36.text:
relativity, and sacrifice their lives for
their enemies?”

862.52.text:
I can’t imagine how long it took this straw
man to crawl out of the sludge that’s slopping

867.41.text:
around between your ears and navigate its
way through your digestive tract to freedom,

872.13.text:
but judging from the stench that’s accompanied
it I suspect that it was some time. I’m

877.14.text:
not sure if you should be more ashamed of
yourself for producing such an unashamedly

881.03.text:
insincere question or such an extraordinarily
retarded one.

885.87.text:
The evolution of adaptive intelligence was
one of the primary drivers for our success

889.74.text:
as a species. Our development as social animals,
however, may arguably have been equally important

895.50.text:
for we are undoubtedly more successful in
groups than we would be as individuals. Selection

900.56.text:
for altruism (which is not, incidentally,
unique to humans) and for positive group behaviors

905.68.text:
which manifest themselves as what we now call
morality, would undoubtedly given our ancestors

910.39.text:
a competitive reproductive advantage.
Intelligence on the other hand, led us to

914.68.text:
formulate solutions to increasingly complex
problems. In more primitive times, however,

919.70.text:
many natural phenomena seemed inexplicable,
and so this intelligence was applied to concocting

924.45.text:
fantastic explanations in terms that could
be understood at the time – that is by resorting

929.54.text:
to the vagaries of suspiciously anthropic
gods. It may have escaped your notice, Casey,

934.81.text:
but the path of history is strewn with the
desiccated corpses of countless gods and goddesses

940.07.text:
whose existence was as blindly unquestioned
by their followers as the existence of yours

944.37.text:
is by you.
Eventually, though, that intelligence was

947.50.text:
put to more productive use following the development
and formalization of the process known as

951.69.text:
the scientific method, which only further
facilitated our success as a species. This

956.79.text:
also allowed humanity to eschew spurious supernatural
and superstitious rationalizations in favor

962.02.text:
of explanatory and predictive utilitarian
models of reality based on empirical and objective

967.13.text:
evidence - models that include Einstein’s
Theory of General Relativity.

971.94.text:
All of this can be explained in terms of Darwinian
evolution, but only to those who wish to listen

976.66.text:
and understand, rather than stick their heads
up their arses to prevent the intrusion of

980.47.text:
anything resembling reality into their cherished
fables.

984.43.text:
Just like science, music, art and literature
are all side-effects of the intelligence that

988.49.text:
first arose as a survival strategy on the
African savannah. So if your aim is to imply

993.62.text:
that these human activities could not conceivably
have arisen during biological evolution, then

998.53.text:
kindly explain specifically which parts of
evolutionary theory preclude this possibility

1003.15.text:
and a detailed mechanistic explanation of
why. Otherwise, just shut up and piss off.

1010.34.text:
“Why do so many people believe in God if
evolution wired us to be logical and there

1017.74.text:
is no God?”
Oh for fuck’s sake, Casey. Are you serious,

1023.36.text:
or are you deliberately trying to create the
impression that your brain’s taken a permanent

1028.08.text:
vacation and left your rectum to do your thinking
and talking for you?

1032.47.text:
It’s quite clear from even the most fleeting
of glances at the world around us, or failing

1037.39.text:
that just the questions you’ve been asking,
that the human race is far from “wired to

1041.57.text:
be logical”. It’s only been four-hundred
years since we’ve started to systematically

1046.25.text:
explain the world around us compared to the
millennia of religious mumbo-jumbo that prior

1050.93.text:
to that passed for knowledge.
That kind of historical indoctrination takes

1055.30.text:
a long time to overcome, but fortunately it
does seem that growing scientific literacy

1059.90.text:
is slowly eroding the prevalence of superstitious
thinking that you and your kind seem to be

1064.49.text:
so bent on perpetuating. Of course, all of
this would be happening a lot faster if you

1069.17.text:
and your fellow lying fuckers at the Discovery
Institute would just shut up and piss off.

1075.81.text:
“Why are atheists so obsessed with God?”
I for one give not one shit for your god or

1084.92.text:
anyone else’s, since all the divine beings
I’ve ever heard of seem to me to be quite

1089.12.text:
obviously the figments of human imaginations.
I’m as obsessed with gods as I am with other

1094.75.text:
irrelevant fictions such as fairies, unicorns
and witches; that is to say- not in the fucking

1100.49.text:
least.
And the simple reason is that since they’re

1103.75.text:
all non-existent, none of these things can
affect my life in any way whatsoever, and

1107.82.text:
so they seldom have occasion make me spend
any time even thinking about them. The same

1112.82.text:
applies to your and all other gods, because
they’re as relevant to my life as an inflatable

1117.61.text:
doll is to a eunuch’s.
So when it comes to the moderate theist - the

1122.24.text:
kind that understands that others may not
share their beliefs and have the right not

1125.83.text:
to have them imposed upon them or shoved down
their throats – I have little problem. If

1131.16.text:
these were the only kind of theists in the
world, I’ve little doubt that the concept

1135.41.text:
of god would seldom, if ever, cross my mind.
However, when fundamentalist nut-jobs start

1141.64.text:
trying to tell me how to live my life based
on what they believe, then the issue of God

1146.40.text:
becomes relevant to me. In particular I’ve
become obsessed with standing up to the stupidity

1152.24.text:
and dishonesty of creationists like yourself,
stupidity and dishonesty that you’ve done

1157.16.text:
a fabulous job in demonstrating with your
questions so far. I’ve lost all tolerance

1162.35.text:
for ignorant buffoons who strut out into public
and expect the inane drivel that they’re

1167.57.text:
spewing to be blindly accepted and instead
of challenged. When people like you start

1172.34.text:
to spread your putrid lies, I’m going to
do my very best to point out the stench and

1177.30.text:
exactly where it’s coming from.
So if you want to know why the majority of

1181.65.text:
atheists appear to be so “obsessed” by
God, Casey, it’s really quite simple. It’s

1187.84.text:
because smug, dishonest and wantonly ignorant
little pricks like you simply refuse to shut

1193.88.text:
up and piss off.
“Why are atheists so unilaterally uncivil?”

1202.40.text:
It should be abundantly clear from either
the quite astonishing levels of disingenuousness

1208.35.text:
in the questions you’ve been asking here,
or from the unfortunate mental dysfunction

1212.82.text:
that causes you to pose them, exactly why
some atheists are uncivil. In addition, your

1218.51.text:
very assertion that this behavior is unilateral
is a perfect example of the kind of outrageously

1223.69.text:
mendacious behavior that is positively guaranteed
to have people lining up to call you a slimy

1229.24.text:
little shit-streak of an excuse for a human
being.

1232.61.text:
Because, while I won’t deny that I have
no qualms of, and make no apologies for, telling

1236.99.text:
dishonest twats like you exactly what I think
of them, there are of course plenty of atheists

1241.63.text:
out there who have a lot more patience, respect
and manners than I. Conversely I’ve seen

1246.50.text:
the most hateful and reprehensible behavior
from hordes of theists all over the internet

1251.34.text:
and on my Youtube channel, behavior that make
me look angelic by comparison and that makes

1256.72.text:
the theists that engage in it look like the
most wicked and vile monsters imaginable

1262.17.text:
So for you to claim that rudeness is the sole
domain of the atheist is a true testament

1267.16.text:
to either the magnitude of the brain defect
that’s responsible for your delusions, or

1272.11.text:
a measure the vastness of your disregard for
both truth and decency.

1277.62.text:
And on that note, now that I’ve answered
your questions, I think it’d be best all

1282.07.text:
around if you’d just shut up - and fuck
off.
